column2: Link It Up
What you'll do
In this activity, you'll upgrade your single page website to a multi-page website!
See you later!

"Uh-oh! Looks like Sublime Text isn't installed! You need to download it from the App Center because we'll be using it for this activity. Click the icon named App Center on the Desktop, then search for Sublime Text, and install it. "

Hiya, {{user_name}}! You've mastered how to build your first web page, but most websites have multiple pages. For example, you might have "About Me", "Projects", "Products", or other pages, to give visitors more information.
Let's get started. We've added the files you're going to use in your Documents folder - let's take a look at them.
The lower-left corner of the screen with the icons is called the taskbar. Click the yellow folder icon to launch the File Explorer.
Once you have the File Explorer open, click the Documents link on the left panel of the window, and then open the multiplepages folder.

The folder should contain the about.html, contact.html, favs.html, index.html files and three folders: css, images, and js. The index, about, contact, and favs files are all different pages for your website. If you ever need a refresher of the file names, come back here.

Let's take a look at the page we'll be using in this part of the activity- right-click on the index.html file, and select Open With Google Chrome. (If you're using a Hack laptop, you can click the mouse pad with two fingers to right-click.)
The Chrome browser should launch with your web page. The web page should look familiar because it was built using the same components in the previous Bootstrap activity.
At the top of the page, try clicking on the About Me, My Favorite Things, and Contact Me links in the navigation bar. You'l see pretty quickly that they don't do anything! Let's fix that.
You can do it!
Switch back to your File Explorer by pressing Alt + Tab. We need to look at the files in the multiplepages folder again.

Right-click on the index.html file and select Open With Other Application. In the popup window, if you see Sublime Text highlighted in your Recommended Applications, click the Select button. Otherwise, click the View All Applications, then Sublime Text, and the Select button.

Here's a quick tip: If you need to resize a window, like Sublime Text, hit the windows button + arrow left to snap it to the left. If you press the windows button + arrow right, the window will snap to the right.
Sublime Text will open and display the code for your page. Take a moment to look over the code. Don't worry if you can't find the problem yet, we'll walk you through it. :)

HTML links are defined with the <a> tag, and the link destination is specified with href. Look at line 25 of this file - The href on that line doesn't have a location right now! The link should appear within the quotation marks.
Let's tell the link to point to the index.html file in this folder. Type index.html between the quotation marks. Your link should now look like this: <a href="index.html">

Check out the tab for your file near the top of the Sublime Text window - Notice that there is now a dot on the tab? The dot tells you that you have some unsaved changes. Unsaved changes will not be shown on your webpage, so let's save this file.

Press ctrl + s to save the file with your changes. You'll know the file saved when the dot mark in the tab is replaced with a cross mark (x). Now, each time you hit the Home link, the index.html file will load.
We could test this out, but you wouldn't see anything - Clicking on a link to index.html when we're already at index.html wouldn't do anything! Let's fix the next link in the navigation bar, instead.
Press Alt + Tab to go back to Sublime Text and check out the href link on line 32. Do you notice something missing? You guessed it - the link to the file is missing. Let's fix that.
Type in the following between the quotation marks: about.html Notice that there is now a dot at the tab for your index.html file in Sublime Text. Save your changes by hitting ctrl + s.

Hit Alt + Tab to go back to the Chrome browser tab that says "Hello, world!", refresh the page, and click on the About link in the navigation bar at the top of the page. Your website should now display the About Me page.
Way to go! I'm sending a virtual high-five!
You've just linked your index.html page to about.html! Let's move on to the next link in your navigation bar. Hit the back button on your Chrome browser to return to the previous page.

Hit Alt + Tab to go back to Sublime Text and check out the href link on line 39. Let's add the following link to point to the favs file: favs.html Don't forget to save the Sublime Text file by hitting ctrl + s.
Go back to the Chrome browser tab, refresh the page, and click on the My Favorite Things link in the navigation bar at the top of the page. Your website should now display the new page.
Good work, {{user_name}}. Your procedural thinking has improved by a factor of 5.3.
Let's move onto the next link in your navigation bar. Hit the back button on your Chrome browser to return to the previous page.

Hit Alt + Tab to go back to Sublime Text and check out the href link on line 46. Let's add the following link to point to the contact file: contact.html Don't forget to save the Sublime Text file by hitting ctrl + s.
Go back to the Chrome browser tab, refresh the page, and click on the Contact Me link in the navigation bar at the top of the page. Your website should now display the new page.
One final bit left to go! The text in the cards at the bottom is blue because they're all links - let's fix that by linking our own style sheet on line 12.
In between the quotation marks on line 12, type in css/style.css The line should look like this: <link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style.css">
Don't forget to save index.html file by hitting ctrl + s! Now you can Alt + Tab back to Chrome and refresh the page to see your changes.

Way to go! You've just learned the basics of linking different pages to your website. There are other links for your index page you can fix, such as the cards on lines 106, 120, 134, and the footer on lines 155, 162, 169, and 176. Simply use what you've learned above. That's it!
Awesome! I love what you've done to the site.

You can also fix the links for your other pages such as the About Me, My Favorite Things, and Contact Me pages. Remember, these pages are individual files, so you have to update the links for each page.
Your site looks amazing! Practice makes purrfect!
Mrr#%ow.
And now, of course, you can personalize your website by changing the text and images to whatever you want. Have fun!
